title: 104_hr1404
content:
The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by banning their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines terms such as "article of fur," "interstate or foreign commerce," "import," and "person" for the purpose of regulating the fur trade. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" is defined as a device designed to capture an animal by snapping closed upon the animal's limb. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and government entities subject to US jurisdiction. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES.

No fur article can be imported, exported, or shipped if derived from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or possess such fur, transport leghold traps, or violate regulations. Violators face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 plus two years imprisonment for subsequent offenses. SEC. 4. REWARDS.

The Secretary will pay half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards.

SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, seize, make arrests, and serve warrants for violations of the Act. Any item seized under this Act will be held by an authorized person pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond instead. Forfeited items will be disposed of as prescribed by the Secretary. Fur or steel jaw leghold traps in violation of the Act are subject to forfeiture. The Attorney General can seek injunctions. Any item seized under this Act will be subject to forfeiture to the United States. The Attorney General may seek to enjoin any person alleged to violate the Act or its regulations. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, and it will take effect one year after enactment.
